Award.AwardTitle: NetSE:Large: MONACO: Fundamentals of Molecular Nano-Communication Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanotechnologies are providing a new set of tools to the engineering community to design and manufacture devices in a scale ranging from one to a few hundred nanometers. At this scale, a nanomachine is defined as the most basic functional unit, which is able to perform only very simple tasks, such as computing, data storing, sensing and actuation. Nanonetworks, i.e., the interconnection of nanomachines in networks, will expand the capabilities of single nano-devices by providing them a way to cooperate and share information. Traditional communication technologies based on electromagnetic waves need to undergo a profound rethinking in order to meet the requirements of these networks. Moreover, there are specific applications of nanonetworks in which the utilization of electromagnetic waves is not feasible, such as in intra-body applications. Alternatively, molecular communication, i.e., the use of molecules to encode and transmit information among nanomachines, represents a radically new communication paradigm that demands novel solutions, including the identification of existing molecular communication mechanisms, the establishment of the foundations of molecular information theory, or the development of architectures and networking protocols for nanomachines. This project will address the above challenges to realize this new communication paradigm.

Intellectual Merit: This project seeks to develop a research area spanning across diverse fields, which include communication and information theory, computer science and biology. Specifically, this project will make contributions along four broad directions. First, the researchers will develop Theoretical Foundations of Molecular Nanonetworks, which include the definition and modeling of the attenuation, delay and noises affecting the emission, propagation, and reception processes in molecular communication. In addition, they will analyze the information capacity of nanonetworks first for a network with only two nodes and then for a network with N nodes, for which the effect of interference and collaborative communication will be taken into account. Second, the researchers will design Protocols for Molecular Nanonetworks based on the development of novel principles, primitives and services. Third, the researchers will implement a Simulation Tool for Molecular Nanonetworks in order to validate the information theoretical results as well as to evaluate the performance of the proposed protocols, by accounting for the interactions in the network molecule by molecule. Finally, the researchers will develop an Experimental Validation Platform for Molecular Nanonetworks by using a concrete testbed based on bacteria communication to verify the correctness of the information theoretical results and the protocols developed within the project.

Broader Impact: The project will pave the way for research in nanoscale communication. The outcomes of this work is expected to have a significant impact on research in nanotechnology, biology and information and communication technologies, since this project will represent the entrance of these three main communities to this converging field and will follow a realistic and integrated approach. The range of potential applications of nanonetworks is astonishingly wide, covering from intra-body networks for health monitoring, cancer detection or drug delivery, amongst others, to chemical attack prevention systems. The principal investigators teach a variety of classes in Georgia Tech spanning information theory, network algorithms, communication protocols and biology. They will immediately incorporate output from the proposed research into their classes. The team will develop an open source simulation tool to test the solutions developed and the tool will be made available for public use. This tool will represent the first simulation tool for molecular nanonetworks and will also be used in class projects as an educational tool to provide insights and deep understanding of nanosensor/actuator networks. Scientific results will be disseminated at international conferences, journals and magazines in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interconnection of nanotechnology-enabled devices, or nanomachines, leads to nano-communication networks, i.e., nanonetworks, which stands at the intersection of nanotechnology, biotechnology, and electrical engineering. Nanonetworks cover a large area of domains from the biomedical field, e.g., intra-body diagnosis and intelligent drug delivery, to the industrial fields, e.g., the monitoring and control of production and waste disposal, as well as security/safety applications, such as biological and chemical attack detection. Limited capabilities of the nanomachines in terms of computation, data storage, and range of sensing and actuation, can be mitigated by nanonetworks by providing information transfer to cooperate and coordinate. 

The focus of the Fundamentals of Molecular Nano-Communication Networks (MoNaCo) project is on the molecular communication(MC) paradigm, where molecules are used to encode, transmit, detect, and decode the information. The research on the design of bio-compatible nanonetworks inspiring from the networking principles already available in nature has been driven by the prospect of the new biological and industrial applications that require communication at the micro-scale. Bacteria is one of the most promising candidates for realizing such a network, which can be genetically engineered to carry out desired sensing, actuation, and above all, communication tasks. Therefore, molecular communication research stands at the intersection of the electrical engineering, biology, and mechanical engineering disciplines. The outcomes of this interdisciplinary research set the fundamentals of the future research and provide the first steps towards practical molecular nanonetworks. In particular, the following items can be listed as the key outcomes of this project:

Theoretical Foundations:

1. The statistical modeling  and analysis of the noise sources in diffusion-based MC.

2. The derivation and the analysis of the capacity of the diffusion-based MC.

3. The modeling of Inter-Symbol and Co-Channel Interference in diffusion-based MC.

4. The study of bacteria-based biotranceivers.

5. The investigation of the relaying performance in N-node bacteria network based on the quorum sensing paradigm.

6. The analysis of error-control coding for molecular communication.

7. The introduction and performance analysis of a new communication technique called Time Elapse Coding (TEC), which encodes information in the time interval between signals.

8. The study of the source addressing and medium access control in bacterial communication networks.

9. The sampling and the detection of the molecular signals using the bacterial receivers.

10. The modeling of the molecule transport, noise and memory for microfluidic channels.

11. Investigation of the physical capacity of microfluidic molecular communication channel

12. The study of Rate-distortion in molecular signal sensing with ligand receptors and optimal quantizers. 

Simulation Tool

13. The development of the simulator framework in Network Simulator 3 (NS-3) which incorporates the molecular communication framework developed under this project.

Validation Platform

14. The characterization of the time response of bacteria fluorescence to C6-HSL signal molecules in receiver cells in bulk culture and in the microfluidic device. 

14. Genetic engineering of transmitter and receiver bacteria through the design of biological circuits.

15. Engineering of microfluidic platform to host, incubate, and probe genetically engineered bacteria.

16. The modeling and validation of bacterial gene expression in microfluidic environments.

17. The design of the two-node microfluidic system to test molecular communication among distinct bacteria populations.

The realization of molecular nanonetworks however demands novel engineering solutions, including the identification of existing molecular communication mechanisms, the establishment of the foundations of molecular information theory, or the development of architectures and networking protocols for nanomachines. These new findings within the MoNaCo project have greatly increased our knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects in molecular communication networks. By this project, we established the theoretical foundations of molecular nanonetworks to pave the way for this new networking paradigm and set the basis for future research and defines the first steps towards real implementable solutions.

For the broader impact of the project, the research results will be incorporated into the Information and Network Theory and Wireless Communication and Networks within the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, at the Georgia Institute of Technology, both at undergraduate and graduate levels. 8 PhD students and 1 Post-doctoral fellow were involved and trained to become experts in this fast evolving field. 1 Master student developed the first simulation tool for molecular nanonetworks incorporating the collective research effort of the team which  will also be used in class projects as an educational tool to provide insights and deep understanding of nanosensor/actuator networks. The research results are disseminated in first-rate scientific conferences, journals and premier magazines of the field.
